displayed_text: Patient: One slot. Okay. So, if it is filled by the end of next week. Let’s say I, uh, decide not to, uh, take it. Um. Doctor: That person has to be on treatment for a month. And then they -- Patient: December. Doctor: Then they can decide that there’s now three more spots, you know. Patient: It would be six more slots in group three. It says, “Six cohorts groups of up to six subjects.” Doctor: Right. So, they do three. And if any of them have a bad side effect, they have three more. Patient: Oh. Doctor: That’s where the cohorts come up to six. Patient: Come up to six. Okay. So, so, it can - alright. Doctor: I’m willing to accept one out of three people having trouble. Um. And so, if we see one out of three, we don’t know whether it is actually more, so we add six. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, if two out of six get into trouble, then we stop. Patient: Okay.

Patient: That’s fine. Doctor: No pain? Patient: I don’t even get the pain when I’m sitting around the house. Doctor: Really? Patient: When I go to sleep at night… Doctor: Okay, maybe it’s not that bad. Okay, push down on mine. Push, push, push. Patient: Push, just push Doctor: Yes. Pull up towards me. (Paper rattling and thumping) Patient: Yeah, no, like I said, at work, I don’t have any problem with walking around, but since, I say, I noticed that I was gettin’ that pain, and it was startin’ to become an irritant to me where I used to didn’t have that problem. You know? Doctor: Now, are you using anything for pain? Patient: No. I didn’t want to do that until I talked to you. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to give you a prescription? Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: One caveat is, and this is going to seem more paradoxical, is that where patients go in this high-risk testosterone trial, the Transformer Trial, they also have to continue the Lupron. Patient: Lupron. Doctor: Which is a hormone-suppression. Patient: Yeah, yeah, we’ve had that before. Doctor: And that may seem paradoxical to you because on the one hand I’m telling you we’re going to give you testosterone back, and on the other hand I’m telling you we’re going to be giving you Lupron to suppress the testosterone. And it turns out this this is exactly what we want to do. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the purpose of this therapy, which we also call bipolar androgen therapy or BAT for short. We call it bipolar, not because it makes the patients bipolar. Doctor: But because we reach two extreme opposite levels of testosterone, opposite poles. Patient: Excuse me; does it have to be Lupron or it could be another hormone? Doctor: It has to be an injectable testosterone-lowering medication. It doesn’t have to be specifically Lupron. It can be any of the injectable hormone therapies. It cannot be an oral hormone therapy. Patient: Right. Okay, okay. Doctor: And typically it’s one of the hormone therapies that’s injected either every three months or every six months.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh You’d think it was a full moon today, crazy things are happening. (pause10sec) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh no new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: So you’re taking Napercin or Patient: For the nerves. Doctor: Napercin is a – for – like Ibuprofen uh like you had something for your bathroom Patient: That - That was a long time ago. Patient: Yes. Yep. Doctor: And atorvastatin forty milligrams times a day? Patient: Yep.

Patient: The nurse, his nurse is mailing me the paper forms, but I will, I’m just going to tell M_ when I walk up in here. Because then it shows right up in my record; you guys have it in a day or two. Doctor: Yep. Patient: I don’t have to deal with one extra fax. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And all that. Doctor: So, April seventeenth for me and then come in any time before that for PSA. Family Member: Like by the tenth. Doctor: And, then, we’re going to skip Dr. S_’s appointment on April sixteenth, and then we’ll just follow with me subsequently. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, um, um, Patient: By then, I will have had my – Doctor: I think you can get your hormone shot.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …so that when you go off on vacation you know what’s gonna happen when you come back. Patient: And I don’t make any airline arrangements from hereon. Doctor: Okay. Alright without checkin’. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, that you know what our treatment plan is. So we can either preferred would be to biopsy before you go so while you’re on vacation we’re working on all of the stuff. And then when you get back we have a plan of either these pills, standard chemo, or chemo on a study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we actually have another study which may or may not be open in time which is a pill plus another pill. The pill is Patient: I’m available all day tomorrow. Doctor: Okay. I will have to work with the group to see what they can do to get that. Patient: Or or I can, I can be s - I can be wherever I need to be at like seven o’clock on Wednesday morning. Doctor: Okay. Okay.

Patient: Yeah, yeah, okay. Doctor: I think after the weekend everyone’s waking up slowly. Patient: My wife just went down… Doctor: Yeah I met her. Patient: Okay did ya? Doctor: She said well yeah just start talking to the two of you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright I’ll be, there she is. (Doctor walking away) Family Member: That’s how I knew how to say her last name. Her husband was in training while I was here. Patient: Oh is that right? Family Member: In radiation oncology. Patient: Oh.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Not through the antigen receptor, which is all those IT doesn’t expand these but a completely different way to shut down the cell. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, but you have to figure out where you are in that trial. So the first thing she needs to do is be able to test your specimens for this particular marker. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So that’s the first thing. The second thing is that if we do get you on, probably the top three side effects would be tiredness. Patient: Hmm, I’m an expert on that. Patient: Yeah, fortunately you know - Doctor: Mm hmm and you weren’t too bad. Patient: You know being a retiree, Doctor: Yeah, Patient: I mean I can sleep.

Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything” Patient: Yeah I quit Lupron for that reason. Doctor: And you're just like, oh, man, I can't do it. Patient: So, what was the other doctor’s name? Doctor: J____. Family Member: J____. Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Like a while ago or recent? Patient: Probably a year ago, I’m guessing. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh, full body, full body MRI? Doctor: No. That site. Because you had the back issue. You do have a nice amount of arthritis as I recall and disk issues there. But, does that seem like it’s the same pain or is it a different pain? Patient: No. It seems to mirror what I was experiencing before. Doctor: Because I think between now and the six weeks that stuffs coming out of you, you decide whether, you know, if it’s looking like even week three of our six-week little holiday here, you go, yeah, you know what, this stuff’s really not getting any better. You call us. We’ll just order the MRI. Poof. Done. Family Member: He’s supposed to see Dr. V___ in a couple of weeks. Doctor: Good. Good. Patient: I think it’s July second - Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Mmm, Okay. Doctor: That deal with this medication. So, Patient: Because I’ve got a mail order through my job, too. Doctor: Which one? Patient: My mail order is called E-h-i-m. They deal with mail order prescriptions. Doctor: Okay. This one, though, has to go to a specialty pharmacy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, what I’ll do is I’ll send it in to D__, which is one of the ones in M___. And, then, if your insurance requires it to go to a certain pharmacy, we can Patient: Okay. Doctor: Transfer it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But, if they call you saying there is payment involved, there is issues like that for the medication, call us first.

Patient: Yeah. Right. Right. Yeah. Not too much. Doctor: Not too much. Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Everything went okay and smoothly? Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. I’m fine. Yeah. Patient: So we get the shot right here? Doctor: Yeah. Yes. So how do you like the new trailer? Slowly, then the scans, everything is going to move here. Patient: Really? Doctor: Two years. Patient: Two years? Yeah. Family Member: Are they building a bigger building? Doctor: They are. Okay. That’s fine. Going to expand quite a bit. We were kind of bursting at the seams there so they needed to do it, but it’s going to be on a much bigger scale.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are. Doctor: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things. Patient: Hum. Doctor: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care. Patient: I get it. Doctor: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care. Family Member: Right. Doctor: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it. Patient: I’m with you. Doctor: Because you know it was nasty when we started. Family Member: I know.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They -

Patient: I lost five more pounds. I got to gain my weight back. Doctor: Well yeah you got to get your teeth back in. Patient: I’m going, I’m going, I’m making the appointment Thursday. I’m going and having them take these out of here. I don’t know, I might have to pay for some more because I don’t think my insurance will cover this, but I want – I’m gonna do it anyway. Doctor: See what they say. Meanwhile though I need you to be drinking those Ensure cans. Two to three a day. Patient: I got it your husband he wrote me a thing to go down there and get me two case. I’m gonna get a case of Ensure and Boost. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here… Doctor: Okay, good. Yeah. Patient: …I’m gonna have my weight is gonna grow back. Doctor: Alright. Good. I’m gonna hold you to it. Patient: And you know when I tell you something (laughs) Patient: You know that’s how it be doc you know that, you know that. Doctor: Okay so when did I last give you this uh medication? When are you going to go fill them?
